required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Assessment of Suppression of Cutaneous Allergic Responses and Pruritis by Topical Minocycline
clinical_study.official_title: Assessment of Suppression of Cutaneous Allergic Responses and Pruritis by Topical Minocycline

lead_sponsor.agency: State University of New York - Downstate Medical Center

clinical_study.source: State University of New York - Downstate Medical Center

brief_summary.textblock: Adults with known respiratory allergy/asthma with known skin test sensitization will undergo repeat skin prick testing at 4 areas of both arms (bilateral forearms, bilateral upper arms). Each site will be challenged with up to three known allergens, saline and histamine controls. Mean wheal diameter after 20 minutes challenge will be determined. This is followed by placement of minocycline cream (0%, 1%, 2%, 3%), placed in randomized fashion at each of 1 of 4 skin test sites. Measurement of subsequent wheal diameter will be done at 30 minutes, 60 minutes and 24 hours.

detailed_description.textblock:
Adults with known respiratory allergy/asthma with known skin test sensitization will undergo repeat skin prick testing at 4 areas of both arms (bilateral forearms, bilateral upper arms). Each site will be challenged with up to three known allergens, saline and histamine controls. Mean wheal diameter after 20 minutes challenge will be determined. This is followed by placement of minocycline cream (0%, 1%, 2%, 3%), placed in randomized fashion at each of 1 of 4 skin test sites. Measurement of subsequent wheal diameter will be done at 30 minutes, 60 minutes and 24 hours.
In addition, itch assessment at each site will be done at baseline, 30 minutes, 60 minutes and 24 hours using VAS and questionnaire.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Each subject will simultaneously be tested for responses to placebo (0%), 1%, 2% and 3% minocycline cream responses to induced allergic skin inflammation.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in mean diameter of treatment induced effect on wheal size
primary_outcome.description: Compare mean diameter of placebo associated mean wheal diameter vs. 1%, 2%, and 3% minocycline cream

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in itch scores by minocycline 1%, 2%, and 3% vs. placebo
secondary_outcome.description: Changes in both visual analogue scale (0 to 100mm, with greater itch being with higher scores) and verbal itch scores (0 to 3, with 0 being no itch and 3 being severe itch) with 1%, 2%,and 3% cream vs, placebo over time.

intervention.description: Placement of minocycline cream 0%, 1%, 2% or 3% at one of four identical allergen skin test sites.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Adult ( ages 18-75) outpatients with diagnosis of allergic rhinoconjunctivitis and/or asthma who have previously undergone epicutaneous skin prick testing with detection of at least one allergen positive.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Subjects who are unable/unwilling to undergo cessation of oral antihistamines for five days prior to testing.
- Current use of oral steroids or other systemic immunosuppressants, including omalizumab (anti-IgE therapy) and anti-IL-5 therapy.
- Allergic asthmatics who have current uncontrolled asthma.

overall_official.affiliation: State University of New York - Downstate Medical Center

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: State University of New York - Downstate Medical Center
